G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify a custody or parenting time order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and when modification is in the best interests of the child.

See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that the best interests of the child shall govern custody and parenting time decisions.
See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that under the removal statute the key question is whether removal is in the best interests of the child, and then elaborates a best-interests analysis for both custody and removal. The court affirms that the “best interests of the child” standard governs and applies it to determine physical custody and relocation, thereby supporting the proposition that Massachusetts custody/parenting-time decisions are governed by the child’s best interests.
See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change…”}

See Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (20.proposition: The failure of a parent to ensure consistent school attendance has been recognized as grounds for modification of custody or parenting time.
See Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses legal and physical custody, the parents’ relative abilities to meet the children’s special emotional and educational needs, and the procedural vehicle for modifying custody (complaint for modification vs. motion). It does not mention school attendance, truancy, or any failure by a parent to ensure consistent school attendance as a basis for modifying custody or parenting time. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
See Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (20.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.raw_text: See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.proposition: Shared legal custody requires the ability of parents to communicate and cooperate effectively in matters of importance to the child’s welfare, including education.
See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses when joint or shared custody is appropriate and expressly ties it to the parents’ ability to agree on major child-rearing issues and to work together in decision-making. The court emphasizes that joint custody requires a willingness and ability to cooperate on major decisions, including schooling and education, and finds joint custody inappropriate here because the parents fundamentally disagree on such issues. This aligns closely with the proposition that shared legal custody requires effective parental communication and cooperation in matters important to the child’s welfare, including education.
See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … ‘[J]oint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’ … [T]he parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education….”

See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material and substantial decline in a child’s academic performance constitutes a significant change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 208, § 28 only to correct the trial judge’s error in finding that the mother’s remarriage was not a post‑judgment change in circumstances. It identifies remarriage as a material and substantial change but does not address academic performance or any decline in a child’s academics as a qualifying change. There is no language treating a change in school performance as the basis for modification under § 28, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred…’). In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances….”

See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.proposition: Courts have consistently emphasized the critical importance of educational stability for a child’s development.
See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.support_reasoning: The opinion emphasizes the importance of general stability and continuity in a child’s custodial placement and relationship with a primary caregiver, not specifically educational stability. References to the child’s “school year” schedule and the mother being more attuned to “educational” needs are factual considerations within a broader best‑interests analysis, not a doctrinal statement that educational stability is critically important. The holding and reasoning focus on preserving existing living arrangements and caregiver continuity rather than establishing any distinct principle about educational stability as such.
See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. C.raw_text: See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996).
See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. C.proposition: A parent’s refusal to follow through with agreed-upon services, such as tutoring, is contrary to a child’s best interests.
See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether separating identical twin siblings between two parents serves their best interests and criticizes the trial judge’s excessive reliance on the children’s preferences. It does not discuss a parent’s refusal to follow through with agreed-upon services such as tutoring, nor does it frame such refusal as contrary to a child’s best interests. Thus, it provides no authority for the specific proposition cited.
See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. … We have examined both the record from the proceedings below and the judge’s notes from his private interview with Rebecca and find no evidence from which the judge properly could have concluded that a split physical custody arrangement would be in the childrens’ best interests.”

See Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: See Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 156 (2001).
See Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Court may reduce parenting time if a parent’s behavior disrupts the child’s welfare.
See Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with modification of child support and attorney’s fees, not parenting time or visitation. Although it briefly notes allegations of abuse and parental conflict affecting the children’s emotional condition, the court does not discuss, order, or affirm any reduction in parenting time as a remedy. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses judicial authority to reduce parenting time based on a parent’s disruptive behavior toward the child’s welfare, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
See Pearson v. Pearson, 52 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “As to the former wife’s doubtfully relevant claim that the children — ages twenty and seventeen at the time of the trial — were physically and emotionally abused by their father, the record contains vividly contrasting versions of what happened and, why. Doctor Paul R. Duffly, a psychologist appointed by the court with consent of the parties, found, based on interviews with the children, that postdivorce conflict between the parents has contributed to the children’s deteriorating emotional states.”

See Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924.raw_text: See Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924 (1998).
See Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924.proposition: Modification to sole legal custody is appropriate when one parent fails to make decisions in the child’s best interests.
See Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924.support_reasoning: The opinion affirms an award of sole legal and physical custody to the mother, but it does so based on general best‑interests analysis, parental conflict, and primary caretaker status, not on a finding that one parent failed to make decisions in the child’s best interests. The court does not articulate any rule that modification to sole legal custody is appropriate when a parent fails to make best‑interest decisions; rather, it emphasizes the trial judge’s broad discretion and the statutory best‑interests standard. Thus, it does not establish the specific proposition claimed.
See Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 924.relevant_excerpt: “Where the judge in this case found that the relationship of the parties has been dysfunctional, virtually nonexistent, and one of continuous conflict, he properly determined that custody should be awarded to only one parent. G. L. c. 208, § 31. … In deciding that that parent should be the mother, he properly considered several factors including those that the mother had been the primary caretaker of the child in a marriage where the parties never lived together and the child’s preference was to remain with the mother.”

See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (20.proposition: Frequent truancy and lack of educational support can justify significant changes to custody arrangements.
See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address truancy, lack of educational support, or any educational issues as a basis for modifying custody. Instead, it concerns statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and holds that a fit mother with sole legal custody was free to relocate and that the judge lacked authority to order her return, emphasizing stability and the mother’s relocation rights. Nothing in the reasoning suggests that frequent truancy or educational neglect can justify significant custody changes, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
See Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (20.relevant_excerpt: "Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move. After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate."
